A dangerous career trap no one talks about

‚Ü≥ Not skill gaps.
‚Ü≥ Not weak networking.
‚Ü≥ Not poor time management.

It is: competing in your someone else's lane.

You're talented. Hardworking.
Always pushing to be better.
That's exactly why this matters.

According to McKinsey's 2023 State of Organizations report:
The most resilient professionals aren't those who compete better.
They're those who create new competitive advantages.

While everyone fights to be the best,
The winners focus on becoming the only.

Here are 7 surprisingly simple ways to stop competing and start winning:

1. Strategic Generosity
‚Ü≥ Share freely.
‚Ü≥ Protect your signature methods carefully.
‚Ü≥ Give value before asking anything in return.

2. Choose Blindspots Over Benchmarks
‚Ü≥ Find gaps.
‚Ü≥ Master overlooked skills.
‚Ü≥ Become the expert everyone desperately needs.

3. Build Your Career Superpower
‚Ü≥ Be unique.
‚Ü≥ Combine rare skills.
‚Ü≥ Create a category where you're the only player.

4. Play the "Infinite Game"
‚Ü≥ Skip trends.
‚Ü≥ Build future skills.
‚Ü≥ Master capabilities your industry needs tomorrow.

5. Turn "Weaknesses" Into Weapons
‚Ü≥ Own quirks.
‚Ü≥ Transform flaws.
‚Ü≥ Convert your critics' complaints into your advantages.

6. Use the "Legacy Loop"
‚Ü≥ Design roles.
‚Ü≥ Reimagine solutions.
‚Ü≥ Create entirely new ways of solving old problems.

7. Design Your "Influence Engine"
‚Ü≥ Build trust.
‚Ü≥ Share others' wins.
‚Ü≥ Create networks that amplify your impact everywhere.

Think about it: Netflix didn't beat Blockbuster by being a better video store.
They changed the game entirely.

The fastest way to win isn't by beating the competition.
It's by making the competition irrelevant.

What career rule did you break and win?

 Followfor impactful career insights.

The 7-step playbook to streamline software development:

Step 1: Define Clear Objectives: Nail down exactly what you need your software to do. Make it sharp, make it measurable. No fluffy goals here.

Step 2: Choose the Right Tech Stack: Don‚Äôt just go trendy. Pick tech that actually fits what you‚Äôre building and scales smoothly.

Step 3: Implement Agile Methodologies: Keep things flexible and fast. Agile isn‚Äôt just a buzzword - it‚Äôs your roadmap to quicker, smarter iterations.

Step 4: Automate Testing: Bugs aren‚Äôt cute. Get automated tests running early and keep them going to squash bugs before they bite.

Step 5: Use DevOps Practices: Fuse your development and operations teams. Tighten up the feedback loop and pump out updates faster and more reliably.

Step 6: Monitor Performance: Keep your eyes on the prize. Use real-time monitoring to know exactly how your application is performing and what your users are saying.

Step 7: Iterate Based on Feedback: Act on what you learn. Update your software regularly based on real user feedback and hard data. Keep evolving.

comments.commentText: Solid breakdown of the software development process!

The Number One Cause of Failure.

Success starts with clarity. Without it, your chances of achieving your goals are virtually zero.

Clarity is the foundation of everything in leadership and teamwork. It means having a crystal-clear understanding of your goals, your roles, and your plan of action. Yet, so many projects, strategies, and initiatives falter because people are left guessing. Guessing what success looks like. Guessing who‚Äôs responsible for what. Guessing the next step.

When there‚Äôs no clarity:
 Effort is wasted on the wrong priorities.
 Miscommunication leads to conflict and frustration.
 Teams lose motivation because they can‚Äôt see a clear path forward.

On the other hand, when clarity is present:
 Teams align and work with purpose.
 Productivity soars as people know exactly what‚Äôs expected.
 Confidence builds because everyone understands how success will be achieved.

Clarity doesn‚Äôt just improve your odds of success‚Äîit guarantees you‚Äôll avoid failure caused by confusion and misalignment. Every great achievement starts with the leader painting a vivid picture of what success looks like.

Remember, confusion kills execution. Success starts with clarity. Always.

Repost this to help your network & follow me Gordon Tredgold for more content like this.

These conversations exposed me to fresh ideas, new trends, and cutting-edge technologies that I might have missed otherwise.

 The Growth Mindset Shift: Over time, I realized that attending tech events wasn‚Äôt just about networking it was about evolving. postsData.content:
New Month, New Mindset: The Power of Micro-Goals for February

As we step into February, let's embrace the mantra: "New Month, New Mindset." This is more than just a catchy phrase‚Äîit's an opportunity to recalibrate, refocus, and reignite our passions with purpose.
Often, we set grand resolutions at the start of the year, only to feel overwhelmed or discouraged when progress stalls. What if the key to lasting success isn‚Äôt in massive leaps but in small, intentional steps? Enter micro-goals.
Micro-goals are bite-sized, achievable objectives that keep you moving forward without the weight of overwhelming expectations. They create a roadmap of consistent progress, fostering a sense of accomplishment with each milestone reached. Whether it's reading ten pages a day, dedicating five minutes to mindfulness, or reaching out to a mentor weekly‚Äîthese small actions compound into transformative results over time.
To young leaders and dreamers: remember that success isn‚Äôt a sprint; it's a marathon of meaningful strides. Set clear, specific micro-goals for February. Celebrate your wins, learn from your challenges, and stay committed to the journey.
Your future self will thank you for the steps you take today.

postsData.name:
Adam Robinson
Adam Robinson
postsData.content:
A CEO friend of mine raised $40M at $400M valuation. Two years later? The money‚Äôs gone and his ARR is flat. If you asked him the biggest mistake he made he would tell you: hiring salespeople. Here's why:

To be clear, it wasn‚Äôt JUST hiring salespeople‚Ä¶ It was HOW he hired them.

Another founder buddy of mine recently did a Private Equity (PE) round.

His investors were pushing him to grow his team of reps from 5 to 20.

Fortunately, my PE backed friend talked to my CEO friend first.

Here's how that conversation went:

PE Backed Friend (PBF): We just raised $25m and they want us to hire a bunch of salespeople.

CEO: Of course they do. But don‚Äôt do it yet. That pressure is EXACTLY what smoked me, wasted 2 years and $40m, and very likely shaved 10 years off my life.

PBF: Ok‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ what do I do?

CEO: Are all of your reps at 100%?

PBF: Not really. One might be, the rest aren‚Äôt.

CEO: Do not hire ONE MORE REP until ALL of your reps are at 100% capacity. If you build a machine that has slack in it already, you will experience all sorts of cultural and motivational problems. The same amount of demos your marketing machine is creating and reps are capturing will go to even MORE people. Your team will miss numbers week in and week out. You will attempt to solve that problem by demanding reps you hired to be AE‚Äôs do more and more outbound. That will not work. Your sales leader will probably either quit or be fired, because you‚Äôll have the exact same productivity on 4x the team size.

PBF: That‚Äôs terrifying. Especially now that we‚Äôre PE backed.

CEO: Tell me about it.

PBF: What do I do instead?

CEO: Before you hire a SINGLE REP, make sure all of your reps are at 100% capacity. Make sure your marketing machine can actually produce more pipeline. If and when you can actually flood your reps with activity and the entire team is at 100%‚Ä¶

PBF: Then I hire reps?

CEO: NO!!!! Absolutely not. You work on raising the 100% higher. Figure out how you increase the capacity of the existing team to handle the increased pipeline generation. Can you create AI agents that save account research and follow up time? Can you hire sales assistants to do some of the unavoidable repetitive work? ANYTHING to get your already 100% capacity reps more productive. THEN‚Ä¶ AND ONLY THEN‚Ä¶ Do you start slowly adding reps onto the team.

PBF: I am so glad I spoke to you before I did anything.

CEO: Me too.

TAKEAWAY

Institutional capital still wants to push founders into rapidly hiring reps to accelerate growth.

While that sometimes works, it‚Äôs VERY easy to do it the wrong way.

What‚Äôs the RIGHT way?

1. Make sure your marketing machine can grow
2. Get all your reps to 100% capacity
3. Raise that capacity as much as possible
4. Slowly add reps to THAT machine

Build your team that way and you can‚Äôt lose.

comments.commentText:
Throwing bodies at the problem doesn't work in sales, doesn't work in dev, doesn't work in marketing, doesn't work in...etc. etc.. 

We had an advisor once that upon us plateauing in revenue "Just raise more".

We didn't. :)

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on maximizing current team capacity before scaling is crucial. Smart growth is sustainable growth! üöÄ

I‚Äôm terrified of hospitals. But my knee surgery showed me how Revenue Teams should improve their Buyer Experience.

Yesterday, I underwent a minor knee surgery. A simple meniscus repair.

Now, I‚Äôm afraid as hell of needles, blood, knives‚Äîanything remotely medical. But from the moment I stepped into the hospital, I felt an unexpected sense of calm.

Why?
Because of two things:

 ùó£ùóøùóºùó∞ùó≤ùòÄùòÄùó≤ùòÄ: Everything was structured. Every step before, during, and after surgery followed a simple, scalable process‚Äîchecklists.

‚Äç‚Äç ùó£ùó≤ùóºùóΩùóπùó≤: Everyone, from the nurse to the anaesthetist to the surgeon, focused on making me feel at ease through human connection and collaboration.

Even during surgery, my surgeon explained each step, ensuring I understood what was happening. It transformed what should have been a stressful experience into a great experience.

Now, here‚Äôs my takeaway for B2B tech:

 What if we treated customer experience the same way hospitals treat patient care?

Too often, marketing, sales, and customer success operate in silos‚Äîhanding customers off between teams like a game of hot potato. But in world-class hospitals, every single person follows the same playbook.

ùóñùóµùó≤ùó∞ùó∏ùóπùó∂ùòÄùòÅùòÄ = A Well-Documented Process of What Good Looks Like. I know how much you like thisÔ∏è

Every action, from pre-surgery prep to post-op care, follows a proven checklist refined over decades.

Whether it‚Äôs a minor procedure or complex surgery, everyone in the hospital aligns on a single process.

B2B teams can do the same. Imagine:
 Marketing, Sales & CS using the same "checklist" for buyer & customer success.
 A collaborative, frictionless experience across the entire customer journey.
 A playbook that ensures every customer interaction is seamless.

The best customer experiences are not random. They are engineered through repeatable, scalable processes‚Äîand they are delivered by people who care.

So, here‚Äôs my question for you:

Some employers won‚Äôt like this, but it‚Äôs the truth:

There‚Äôs no such thing as a bad job ‚Äî only bad leadership.

People don‚Äôt leave job descriptions.

They leave because of:

1/ Incompetent bosses.
2/ Feeling micromanaged.
3/ Toxic workplace culture.
4/ Work-life balance issues.
5/ Lack of trust in leadership.
6/ Lack of growth opportunities.
7/ Feeling overqualified for the role.
8/ Poor communication within the team.
9/ Boredom or lack of challenging tasks.
10/ Mismatch between workload and pay.
11/ Overwork and unrealistic expectations.
12/ Feeling undervalued and unappreciated.
13/ Lack of space for creativity or innovation.
14/ Misalignment between personal and company values.
15/ No opportunities for remote or flexible work arrangements.

The numbers don‚Äôt lie:

 72% of employees leave due to a toxic work environment.

And it‚Äôs a leader‚Äôs responsibility to create a workplace where employees don‚Äôt just stay ‚Äî but thrive.

The more we talk about it,

"You must evaluate me as much as I'm evaluating you." 
Would you say that to your team as a CRO? 


Had a great conversation with(20+ year sales veteran, founder, and former CRO). He shared a powerful perspective on leadership that many C-level executives miss: the higher you climb, the more crucial it becomes to seek evaluation from those you lead.


Here are the hard truths every senior leader should consider:

- Being a C-level executive doesn't mean you have all the answers - it means bearing the responsibility of making decisions based on your team's collective intelligence
- The best feedback on your leadership often comes from those you manage, not those above you
- Creating psychological safety for open feedback is crucial - your title naturally creates a barrier that you must actively work to break down
- Your job isn't to be the smartest person in the room, but to hire them and listen to them


In the full episode, we covered:

- Building resilient sales teams through continuous coaching
- Why most companies fail at coaching their coaches
- How to manage different sales personalities effectively
- Why product teams should be your closest allies in building a coaching culture
- The fine line between managing vs. leading - and why most new sales leaders get it wrong

postsData.content:
7 Signs You're a People-Pleasing Leader:

(and it's hurting your team)

True kindness builds strong teams.

People-pleasing destroys them.

1. You Never Defend Your Team's Boundaries:
‚Ü≥ You accept every "urgent" request, overwhelming your team.
‚Ü≥ Require other leaders to use proper channels, no "just this once."

2. You Play Favourites to Keep Everyone Happy:
‚Ü≥ Rewarding complainers while overloading reliable people.
‚Ü≥ Make decisions based on performance, not who might get upset.

3. You Hide Bad News Because You "Care Too Much":
‚Ü≥ Delaying tough updates, thinking you would hurt your team.
‚Ü≥ Share news promptly with empathy - they need time to plan.

4. You Bury Problems Until They Explode:
‚Ü≥ Worrying about upsetting your boss.
‚Ü≥ Be transparent and share any problem within a day.

5. You Do Performance Reviews at Starbucks:
‚Ü≥ Making serious conversations casual to avoid tension.
‚Ü≥ Stop sugar-coating, share specific examples of needed changes.

6. You Make Inconsistent Decisions:
‚Ü≥ Struggling with decisions, fearing they'll upset someone.
‚Ü≥ Prioritize business needs, not who might get upset.

7. Your Top Performers Are Becoming Toxic:
‚Ü≥ You watch star employees break rules, too afraid to confront them.
‚Ü≥ Have the hard conversation now, before good people leave.

Strong leadership isn't about being liked.

It's about doing what's right for your team.

postsData.content:
ABM is dead. Long live PBM.

(I like calling things ‚Äúdead‚Äù now because I imagine it might annoy some of my friends likeand).

We‚Äôre entering a new era in marketing.

We‚Äôre entering the age of Person Based Marketing (PBM).

Here‚Äôs the idea:

With tools like, advanced data enrichment platforms, and AI, we can now create micro-segments‚Äîhighly specific filters that let us deeply understand and target individuals.

It starts the moment someone visits your website.

We can get person-level intent data simply based on IP address.

built an entire business on this potential.

From there, we can use data enrichment to infer attributes, enhance profiles, and help marketers develop a complete perspective on a person‚Äîwhat they care about, what motivates them, and what they‚Äôre looking for.

Armed with this intelligence, we can deliver hyper-personalized advertising and messaging‚Äîtailored to the person, not just the account.

It‚Äôs a fundamental shift.

PBM transforms how we approach marketing:

- Micro-segmentation lets us design campaigns with pinpoint precision
- AI enables us to target individuals when they‚Äôre most engaged
- Personalization improves conversion rates by speaking directly to what matters most

Now, is it perfect? Not yet.

We‚Äôll have to measure costs and balance efficiency.

But the potential is massive.

That new term that everyone‚Äôs tossing around - GTM Engineer - that will be the person in your growth org that is experimenting with new hyper-focused segments and testing messaging and conversion rates against those micro-segments.

For the first time, we have the tools to make marketing feel truly human‚Äîdelivering the right message to the right person at exactly the right time.

This is something new. One step closer to Minority Report.

Welcome to the age of Person-Based Marketing.

postsData.content:
If someone tells you to jump into self-care 
immediately after a layoff, either they've...

...never been laid off (without something lined up)
OR
aren't taking your situation as serious as it should be.

Either way, it's terrible advice.

Think of a LAYOFF like a burning house.

IF you're house is on fire:

It's shocking
100% an emergency
Going to hurt financially

It's absolutely NOT the time to:

>> to go get a massage
>> to take up goat yoga in your living room
>> to dance around and sing Lizzo's "Special" for a day and take your foot off the gas

And while self-care is important LATER -- it is NOT a priority when your wallpaper is curling and you're tapping doorhandles for heat on the way out.

Nope.

Not yet.

It IS time, however, to grab your 'go bag' and 'get outta that house.'

And by 'go bag' after a layoff, I mean 2 specific things:

1// YOUR CONTACTS
2// YOUR METRICS

Sit down and write out everyone you know,
grab your database that you developed,
download the numbers and
wins that you generated.

These things are your insurance policy for the future.
They will save you in that next interview with Smith & Nephew
when they ask you "so, how much revenue/volume growth did you achieve, and how?"

They'll be your lifeline after that computer is shut off and mailed back to Home Office when you're trying to network with those on the inside and sending thank you notes and reviews (Traction Clients, ikyk).

(and if you're on my email list, you'll soon find out  e x a c t l y  how to do this on Saturday, too. I've got you)

So grab a seat, a pen, and paper -- and write. it. all. down.

This is your Exit Plan.
Your Personal Escape Hatch.
Your Fire Squad at the Ready Should the Worst Happen.

And once you've done that
it's self-care time.

And hey,
if you know that you may need this 'go bag'
what's stopping you from gathering these things before su casa is aflame?

Take it from someone who's been through 5 of these.

Contacts
Metrics
Self-Care

(In that order)

xo
Claire

comments.commentText: Take care of your mental health after losing your job, but secure all important data and contacts from your previous role before resting, Ô∏èClaire M. DavisÔ∏è. You likely will lose access to the data and contacts soon!

postsData.commentAdded: Great analogy, Claire! Prioritizing actionable steps over immediate self-care is crucial after a layoff. Your insights are invaluable!

80% of B2B salespeople will be obsolete by 2037 unless...

If you are hopping from industry to industry and job to job not going deep on any industry to become a true expert in a field...your skills will expire (FYI - mine too)

Prompted: 01 Reasoning Model of ChatGPT: (Preface first I asked it about replacing average reps)

"Ok let's take a step up what about the top 60-80% of reps today who are good at sales but again spend less than 2-3 hours a week learning new trends in their industry or hop jobs every 1-2 years so they never really learn an industry, how soon until they are obsolete"

Now Watch ChatGPT go HARD on this answer: 

Everything below is 100% GenAI:

"For the top 60-80% of reps‚Äîthose who are good but not great, and who aren‚Äôt deeply investing in industry expertise or learning trends‚ÄîAI will start to outpace them in 5-7 years (by 2030-2032), and they will be obsolete in 10-12 years (by 2035-2037).

Here‚Äôs the breakdown:

Short-Term (2025-2028 | 3-5 Years) ‚Üí AI Closes the Gap
These reps are good at selling but not deeply specialized, meaning AI tools will start replicating their skills faster than they expect.

AI will become better at surfacing industry insights and objections in real-time, reducing the need for reps to stay ahead of trends manually.

 Impact: These reps won‚Äôt be obsolete yet, but AI will start making less-experienced sellers just as effective as them‚Äîremoving their competitive edge.

Mid-Term (2028-2032 | 5-7 Years) ‚Üí AI Surpasses Good Sellers

AI-driven sales advisors (not just tools) will be able to personalize messaging, handle objections, and even negotiate standard deals better than these reps.
Buyers will increasingly rely on AI tools for research and vendor selection.

Companies will start favoring highly specialized salespeople (who truly understand an industry and bring strategic insights) over generalist reps who hop jobs frequently.

 Impact: These reps will still have jobs, but their value will be shrinking fast. Companies will start consolidating sales teams.

Long-Term (2032-2037 | 10-12 Years) ‚Üí Full Obsolescence

AI will handle most transactional sales conversations and even many complex ones, leaving only industry specialists and highly strategic sellers.
Sales teams will keep only those who:
 Have deep industry expertise
 Understand business strategy beyond just selling
 Can leverage AI effectively rather than compete with it

 Impact: By 2035-2037, companies won‚Äôt need these reps anymore. The top 20% of salespeople will dominate.

Final Verdict: Timeline to Obsolescence

AI will start catching up to ‚Äúgood‚Äù sellers in 5-7 years (2030-2032).
They will start losing job security by 2032-2035.
By 2037, if they haven‚Äôt specialized or evolved, they will be fully obsolete.

If they want to stay relevant past 2035, they must:
 Deeply specialize in an industry (not just hop jobs)
 Invest in strategic knowledge (not just sales tactics)"

Me: It's 2025...time to get to work

comments.commentText: Interesting. I'm surprised that it didn't highlight some of the oft-overlooked soft skills as a differentiator that helps top performing sellers to continue to be relevant. Obviously, this is a probable outcome based on predictions from AI, but I believe that as much as people embrace AI more over time, there will also be a growing desire for human connection in a world overflowing with AI automation. Sellers (and business professionals in general) who can demonstrate their experience and expertise through exceptional story telling, provide authentic human interactions, and demonstrate critical thinking skills will be the ones who will continue to thrive. *Caveat - if they TOO leverage AI. Those skills alone will not secure one's place. They will be a necessary compliment to required AI skills in a world lacking the human interaction that so many will crave.

7 Simple steps great leaders take to handle conflict.

(Without breaking the bonds with their teams.)

Most leaders avoid conflict.

Great leaders use it to strengthen relationships.

Here are 7 simple steps great leaders take to handle conflict.

1. Create a safe space.
‚Ü≥ Meet privately, away from others.
‚Ü≥ Make it about growth, not blame.

2. Find common ground.
‚Ü≥ Focus on shared team goals.
‚Ü≥ Highlight what's working well.

3. Listen with purpose.
‚Ü≥ Let them speak without interruption.
‚Ü≥ Ask questions to understand deeper.

4. Protect their dignity.
‚Ü≥ Give them space to process.
‚Ü≥ Keep the conversation private.

5. Build solutions as partners.
‚Ü≥ Suggest multiple options.
‚Ü≥ Let them shape the path forward.

6. Follow through.
‚Ü≥ Set clear next steps together.
‚Ü≥ Check in regularly.

7. Reset the relationship.
‚Ü≥ Find opportunities to collaborate
‚Ü≥ Build stronger bonds through action.

The strongest teams aren't the ones without conflict.

They're the ones who handle it with care.

What's your best tip for handling conflicts with care?


Repost to help leaders better handle conflicts.

Ô∏èNavigating the complexities of frontend development interviews can be challenging. To assist fellow developers,

Ô∏èI'm sharing a curated list of essential questions and answers that have been pivotal in my preparation journey. Let's empower each other to succeed! 

Key Questions Covered:

What are meta tags in HTML?
Meta tags provide metadata about the HTML document, such as descriptions, keywords, and author information, which help with search engine optimization and browser behavior.

Can you explain the difference between let, const, and var in JavaScript?
var is function-scoped, while let and const are block-scoped. const is used for variables that shouldn't be reassigned, whereas let is suitable for variables that will change.

What is the purpose of the HTML 'doctype' declaration?
The <!DOCTYPE> declaration informs the browser about the HTML version and how to render the document, ensuring consistent display across browsers.

How does CSS specificity work?
CSS specificity determines which styles are applied to an element when multiple rules match. It's calculated based on the types of selectors used: inline styles have the highest specificity, followed by IDs, classes, and element selectors.

What is a closure in JavaScript?
A closure is a function that retains access to its lexical scope, even when executed outside that scope. This feature allows for data encapsulation and the creation of private variables.

Here's how we've grown TACK into a seven figure business.

The first thing we did was think about the story we wanted to tell the world. We were very intentional with what we were trying to say and build.

We named the business TACK because the word is a sailing term, which is a maneuver that involves turning the bow of a boat through the wind to change direction.

So we took that idea and turned it into a metaphor for business. A business never goes from point A to point B in a straight line. You have to zig and zag to grow. TACK helps businesses find the right tack for their stage, their market, their product, and their customers.

We took it one step further and named a new way to think about how to grow your business.

Why? Because we noticed massive shifts happening and business and marketers need new ways to grow. The biggest thing we identified is, companies match how they market and sell to the why people like to buy things today. The gap between the two continues to increase unless you take a different approach.

We named the problem Company-first GTM.

We call the new approach People-first GTM. A business strategy that uses storytelling, relationships, and partnerships to create, capture, and convert demand into revenue. It‚Äôs designed to put people at the center of every interaction and experience.

I share all this because we are using a People-first GTM strategy to grow TACK and the first thing you need to do is identify and write down your business's stories. The founding story and the problem story.

We built three resources to help people understand and implement the strategy. Drop 'people' in the comments if you want all three.

From there, you can start to think through the different channels and offers you can use to acquire and retain customers.

It all starts with Partner-led Growth. We use it for co-marketing, co-selling, and co-servicing. I'll do a whole other post on how we do it. But TACK would not be nearly as successful if we didn't have a very partner strategy. It helps us create a high margin business.

Community-led Growth powers our audience building and we use LinkedIn and private communities to activate this strategy. It's about finding the right networks to use to grow a rented audience. I say rented because you don't technically own any of the networks or communities.

We then built a Member-led Growth strategy. We created our own community called TACK Insider. It's packed with resources and benefits to help marketers become go-to-market leaders and learn People-first GTM. We knew we had to find a scalable way to bring the concept to people.

Customer-led Growth is how we are able to continue growing with great margins. We're able to expand and grow with our customers, and they are able to help us acquire more new customers.

Alright, I ran out of characters. I'll share more later about how we use content-led growth and a little bit of event-led growth.

postsData.content:
I have thought about the fires in California, and the many who lost their homes, their livelihood, their familiar haunts, and even the security of normalcy.

I have been there - that place of loss - more times than I care to count.

But this past year when visiting my sonand his wife (my first daughter-in-law)in Utah, Emi showed me the Fireweed and explained that it is one of the first things to grow back after a fire. I learned that in England they call it Bomb Weed - as it was discovered in places where bombs fell after WWII.

I decided to create some images in AI that illustrated the hearty bit of unrefined, raw beauty that is part of the recovery.

The oft overlooked wonder of nature, that adds lovely in a place of such devastation and loss - as a reminder of new growth, new possibilities, and even a chance at 'beauty from ashes'.

These - do not look like MJ images at first glance. They do not have the luster of perfectly coiffed and highly choreographed AI images.
They look... dirty, grungy, unpolished, chunky, ill-framed and poorly composed. They look... real.

Super Macro photograph of a Fireweed flower (Chamerion angustifolium) growing from the charred ground of Western California. Depth of Field and Out of focus background revealing burned and charred homes with distant work crews clearing the debris with yellow construction tractors and Bobcats and work trucks. --ar 5:7 --quality 2 --style raw --profile czkxosi --stylize 300 --v 6.1

The reference image is a photo of the Fireweed. Without it, Midjourney produced a 'flower' but it was not the right variety. This heavily influenced the styling - even though I did not choose to make the reference a style image.
I didn‚Äôt know that about bomb weed and I grew up near a few places that were still not built on even 30-40 years after WWII. Recovery does happen. Sometimes quickly. Sometimes slowly.

Chief Executives | CEO, COO, CFO, CTO & CXO's (Investors, Partnerships, Mergers & Deals)
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 4 ‚Äì Update Agent LEARNING
Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (,)

A report in Quanta magazine () provides an example: The idea of a ‚Äúbank‚Äù has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more abstract, really different from what you‚Äôre seeing,‚Äù said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3.



In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not ‚Äúknow‚Äù anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights into how our brains learn compared to LLMs! Excited to see how Agentic Expertise Ecosystem can harness this knowledge.

The secret to becoming a people magnet:

(As an introvert)

Some people walk into a room, and others gravitate toward them.

 Not because they‚Äôre the loudest.
 Not because they demand attention.

But because they make others feel seen.

Here‚Äôs how to do the same:

(without changing who you are)

1Ô∏è‚É£ Master active listening

‚Ü≥ Give people your full attention and respond thoughtfully.
‚Ü≥ Mirror their emotions instead of interrupting - connection starts with understanding.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Cultivate warmth in your body language

‚Ü≥ Smile naturally and keep an open, inviting posture.
‚Ü≥ Maintain comfortable eye contact - engaged, not intense.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Be authentically curious

‚Ü≥ Ask open-ended questions to make others feel valued.
‚Ü≥ Share stories, but keep the spotlight on them.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Share your strengths subtly

‚Ü≥ Let achievements surface naturally through storytelling.
‚Ü≥ The less you force it, the more people admire you.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Respect boundaries, including your own

‚Ü≥ Focus on meaningful interactions, not just socializing more.
‚Ü≥ Give space when needed - connection isn‚Äôt about overstepping.

You don‚Äôt need to be the loudest person in the room.

You just need to be the one who listens, understands, and makes others feel valued.

Because at the end of the day‚Ä¶

People won‚Äôt remember your words.

They‚Äôll remember how you made them feel.

- - -

P.S. What‚Äôs one habit that makes someone instantly likeable to you?
